From a young age, Carter showed a profound talent for rhyming, an interest that would eventually propel him into the music industry. He formed the group, The Jeffries Brothers, with his brother Damon, but it wasn't until they joined forces with producer Jaz-O in 1993 that they released their debut album, "It's All About The Benjamins." The album became an underground hit, marking the beginning of Jay-Z's solo career.

In 1996, Jay-Z dropped his debut solo album, "Reasonable Doubt," and the world was introduced to his magnetic, street-smart lyrical style. The album's success catapulted him to the forefront of the rap industry and earned him a spot on The Source magazine's "Unsigned Hype" list. In 1999, he followed up with "Vol. 2... Hard Knock Life," which showcased a maturing lyricism and featured his iconic hit "Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)."

Jay-Z's entrepreneurial spirit led him to invest in various business ventures, including clothing lines, sports teams, and record labels, such as Roc-A-Fella Records. The success of his record label led to even greater fame and acclaim, cementing his status as a hip-hop mogul.

In 2001, he released his seminal album, "The Blueprint," which solidified his influence on the hip-hop genre and included hit singles such as "Jigga What, Jigga Who." In 2003, he released "The Black Album," featuring collaborations with some of the biggest names in the industry. However, due to a mix-up with his record label, the album was shelved for years before being officially released as "The Black Album Revisited."
